channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Ukraine’s South, Fierce Fighting and Deadly Costs
item.description: The offensive in the south was the most highly anticipated military action of the summer. Ukraine is making gains, but the fighting is grinding, grueling and steep in casualties.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at an entrenched position this month near the Kherson front.

item.title: Iran Protests Surge to Dozens of Cities
item.description: Iranians fed up with oppressive rules and a battered economy have faced bullets, tear gas and arrests to demand an end to the Islamic Republic’s rule.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators on the streets of Tehran this past week. Protests spurred by a woman’s death in custody have expanded to include outrage over economic problems and frustration with moral strictures.

item.title: Italy May Get a Leader With Post-Fascist Roots
item.description: With the hard-right candidate Giorgia Meloni ahead before Sunday’s election, Italy could get its first leader whose party traces its roots to the wreckage of Fascism.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Andreas Solaro/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Supporters of Giorgia Meloni at a joint rally on Thursday for the Brothers of Italy, League and Forza Italia parties in Rome.

item.title: On a Corpse’s Wrist, an Emblem of Ukrainian Fortitude
item.description: When they pulled Serhiy Sova’s body from a grave in Izium, his wrist bore a bracelet in Ukraine’s colors, given to him by his children. The image has transfixed the nation.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators exhumed bodies at the site of a mass grave in Izium this month.

item.title: As Russia Holds Annexation Referendums, Ukraine Pushes to Reclaim Territory
item.description: The fighting continued even as Russian proxies in four Ukrainian provinces began what Western officials have called “sham” referendums to join Russia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Major Covid Holdouts in Asia Drop Border Restrictions
item.description: Hong Kong, Taiwan and Japan have relaxed their pandemic rules, as they look to bolster their economies and play catch-up with much of the world.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Kimimasa Mayama/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Tourists in the Asakusa district of Tokyo this month.

item.title: Some Women Fear Giorgia Meloni’s Far-Right Agenda Will Set Italy Back
item.description: Some fear that the hard-right politician, whose party is expected to be the big winner in the election on Sunday, will continue policies that have kept women back.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni often talks with pride about how she started the Brothers of Italy party and rose to the top of national politics without any special treatment.

item.title: Tasmania Races to Save Pilot Whales After Hundreds Are Stranded
item.description: After 230 pilot whales were stranded on the western coast of Tasmania, a scramble started almost immediately to save as many as possible.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Matthew Newton for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Hocking, center, and other scientists from Tasmanian Museum on Friday examined pilot whales that died after they stranded on a beach along the western coast of Tasmania, Australia.

item.title: In Myanmar, Grief and Fury After an Attack on a School
item.description: Eleven children died when soldiers fired on the school, where they said rebels had taken cover. “This is a war crime,” said a U.N. expert.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Social Media, via Reuters
item.media:description: Damage from the Sept. 16 attack on a school in Let Yet Kone village, in the Sagaing region of central Myanmar.

item.title: How A South African Town Became Buried in Sludge After A Diamond Mine Collapse
item.description: Waste from a diamond mine in South Africa grew ever higher as the ownership changed from De Beers to a billionaire to a Dubai-based retailer. The mining town paid the price.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Lynsey Chutel and Ilan Godfrey
item.media:credit: Ilan Godfrey for The New York Times
item.media:description: When a dam at a diamond mine burst in September in Jagersfontein, South Africa, it coated houses, cars and possessions in six miles of muck. At least one person died.

item.title: Dozens of Migrants Feared Dead After Boat Capsizes Off Syria
item.description: Witnesses said that bodies could be seen from shore drifting in the waters just outside the port of Tartus. The Lebanese authorities said at least 75 people died, with 20 rescued.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad and Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Bilal Hussein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Lebanese Red Cross ambulances carried bodies after a boat carrying migrants from Lebanon capsized in Syrian waters.

item.title: Church of England Stops Desmond Tutu’s Daughter From Officiating Funeral
item.description: Rev. Mpho Tutu van Furth, an Episcopal priest who is married to a woman, said the funeral of her godfather was moved to his garden to allow her to participate.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Lerato Maduna/Foto24/Gallo Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Rev. Mpho Tutu van Furth, right, with her wife, Marceline Tutu van Furth, in Cape Town in 2016.

item.title: Poundbury, England: The Town That Charles Built
item.description: Before King Charles III inherited Britain’s throne, he was a prince with strong views on architecture. Poundbury is where he tried to put them into practice.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Francesca Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Queen Mother Square in Poundbury, a small town in Dorset, southern England. Poundbury is relatively new — construction on it began in the 1990s — but it has a range of historical styles of architecture.

item.title: U.K. Government Goes Full Tilt on Tax Cuts and Free-Market Economics
item.description: The new administration’s plans are a break from the Boris Johnson era and represent a turn toward Thatcherism. The negative reaction from financial markets underscored the extent of the gamble.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson, Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Dylan Martinez
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain, second from left, and Chancellor of the Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng, right, during a visit to a modular building manufacturing company, in Northfleet, England, on Friday.

item.title: ‘Somebody Planted the Guns’: In Canada, a Raided, Distrusting Village Blames the Police
item.description: When a cache of weapons was found in a tiny Canadian village that has become a symbol of the far right, it didn’t take long for new conspiracy theories to start circulating.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: The village of Coutts, Alberta, on the border with Montana, was the site of a large weapons seizure and of antigovernment protests this winter.

item.title: How to Slow Down
item.description: In an age of instant everything, drawing invites us to slow down and appreciate the world around us.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A Year When Everything Is Going Right for Western Canada’s Farmers
item.description: This year’s harvest will be bountiful, with prices more than offsetting increased costs for items like fuel.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: Canada’s farmers are expected to harvest near-record yields this year.

item.title: Defying Travel Warnings, Hasidic Jewish Pilgrims Flock to Ukraine.
item.description: Tens of thousands of Hasidic Jews traditionally travel to Uman to mark Rosh Hashana with a visit to the burial site of a revered 18th-century rabbi.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman/Getty Images
item.media:description: Jewish pilgrims outside the tomb of Rabbi Nachman in Uman, Ukraine, in 2020.

item.title: More Than 700 Children Have Died in a Measles Outbreak in Zimbabwe
item.description: It is driven by a decline in child immunization during the pandemic and the influence of an anti-vaccination evangelical church.
item.dc:creator: Tendai Marima and Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Tsvangirayi Mukwazhi/Associated Press
item.media:description: A mother and baby waiting for measles vaccination at a clinic in Harare, Zimbabwe.

item.title: Vladimir Putin Gets More Involved in Ukraine War Strategy
item.description: The Russian president has rejected requests from commanders in the field that they be allowed to retreat from Kherson, a vital city in Ukraine’s south.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers operate a drone near Kherson, in southern Ukraine. It was the first major city to fall to the Russians in the initial invasion, and remains the only regional capital under Moscow’s control.

item.title: Russia Begins Staged Referendums In Occupied Areas of Ukraine
item.description: Under coercive conditions, with most residents gone and war still raging, Russia is putting on what it calls referendums on annexation but Ukraine and its allies call an illegal farce.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Voters on Friday at a mobile polling station during the referendum on joining Russia, in Luhansk, Ukraine.

item.title: Putin’s Draft Draws Resistance in Russia’s Far-Flung Regions
item.description: Villagers, activists and some elected officials asked why the conscription drive seemed to be hitting poor, remote areas hardest, while pro-war hawks criticized it as chaotic.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: Hilary Mantel Stared Down Her Past, and the World’s, With Steely Resolve
item.description: Hilary Mantel brought great precision to her writing, and asked the same of us in our reading.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: David Levenson/Getty Images
item.media:description: Hilary Mantel “was unsentimental, forthright, unafraid of stating her sometimes fierce views.”

item.title: Group of 7 countries condemn ‘sham’ referendums in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Construction workers lineup to cast ballots at a mobile polling station in Russian-controlled Mariupol in eastern Ukraine on Friday. The referendum has been called a sham by the G7.

item.title: Is Little Amal Getting Lost in New York?
item.description: The hottest celebrity in town right now is an enchanting 12-foot-tall Syrian refugee puppet. She’s drawing masses of admirers, but that’s not always a good thing.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes and Amir Hamja
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Little Amal walking along Central Park West in Manhattan.

item.title: Berlusconi Draws Backlash for Saying Putin Was ‘Pushed’ to Invade Ukraine
item.description: Italy’s former prime minister said that the Russian president was “pushed” to invade Ukraine, remarks that drew fierce criticism days before an election.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Alberto Pizzoli/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Italy’s former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, said President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was “pushed” to invade Ukraine.

item.title: Abel Selaocoe Finds a Home in Improvisation
item.description: The classically trained South African cellist draws on musical traditions from across the globe for his debut album, “Where is Home (Hae Ke Kae).”
item.dc:creator: Hugh Morris
item.media:credit: Adama Jalloh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abel Selaocoe, a classically trained South African artist, is best known for his work on the cello, but is also a singer and improviser. His mixed-genre, groove-orientated approach has won him growing influence in the classical music community.

item.title: What You Need to Know About Italy’s Elections
item.description: The elections could produce the first government led by a woman and by a hard-right party with post-Fascist roots.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Italy’s national elections on Sunday come after the national unity government of Prime Minister Mario Draghi collapsed in July amid a revolt in his coalition.

item.title: The referendums are taking place in areas from which large numbers of people have fled.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Stringer/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A woman cast her ballot at a polling station in the village of Krasny Yar, Luhansk region, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: War Crimes Have Been Committed in Ukraine, U.N. Experts Say
item.description: A three-person Commission of Inquiry set up in April to investigate the conduct of hostilities in four areas of Ukraine laid out the graphic allegations in an unusually hard-hitting, 11-minute statement to the U.N Human Rights Council in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cell where Ukrainian detainees, including civilians, were allegedly interrogated and tortured at the central police station in Kupiansk.

item.title: A Shift in Crime
item.description: Murders are declining, but other crimes are still disrupting American life.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York will install two security cameras on every subway car.

item.title: Where Online Hate Speech Can Bring the Police to Your Door
item.description: Battling far-right extremism, Germany has gone further than any other Western democracy to prosecute individuals for what they say online, testing the limits of free speech on the internet.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chief Prosecutor Frank-Michael Laue surrounded by case files, in the attic of the district attorney’s office in Göttingen, Germany in March, 2022.

item.title: Winter is coming, windows are shattered, and Ukraine is running short on glass.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman

item.title: In Melbourne, a Sky-High Drama Takes Hold
item.description: Peregrine falcons nesting in the city’s financial district offer riveting theater every day with their daily life, including sex, death and high-speed chases.
item.dc:creator: Meghan Dansie

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Interest rate hikes around the world.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers at a food bank in London. The Bank of England on Thursday raised interest rates by half a point to 2.25 percent, even as it said that the United Kingdom might already be in a recession.

item.title: Ukraine War Comes to Russia as Putin Imposes Draft
item.description: As Vladimir Putin’s “special military operation” enters a new chapter, Russians are being plucked from villages around the country for training and military service.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko and Alina Lobzina
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Men Flee Russian Conscription
item.description: Plus Japan props up the yen and Cambodia concludes its Khmer Rouge trials.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Olga Maltseva/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A billboard in St. Petersburg promoting military service.

item.title: Russian Men, Fearing Ukraine Draft, Seek Refuge Abroad
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin’s new military call-up has sent young men who don’t want to fight in Ukraine heading to the borders.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Ozan Kose/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Istanbul International Airport. With the government replenishing its military in Ukraine, some Russian men have headed for the borders.

item.title: Bill to Grant Afghan Evacuees a Path to Residency Hits Snags
item.description: The White House and members of both parties had hoped to attach the legislation to a must-pass spending bill this month. But some Republicans have raised security concerns.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Kennedy, a veteran who served in Afghanistan, traveled from Maine to the Capitol to demonstrate in favor of the Afghan Adjustment Act.

item.title: Catholics Outnumber Protestants in Northern Ireland for the First Time
item.description: Newly released census results may fuel calls for a referendum on uniting Ireland, experts say, but not right away.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sinn Féin campaign posters and a Republican mural on Falls Road, a Catholic stronghold in Belfast, earlier this year.

item.title: Water Problems in Syria Give Rise to Deadly Cholera Outbreak
item.description: The highly contagious disease has spread quickly in the country’s north, where millions of people displaced by a decade-long war are living, and many rely on untreated water from rivers containing raw sewage.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad and Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Delil Souleiman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A child diagnosed with cholera is treated at a hospital in Syria's Deir al-Zour province.

item.title: What to Know About Protests in Iran
item.description: Dozens of cities have been embroiled in protests that were prompted by a young woman’s death in custody but that have escalated amid anger over religious rules and a rock-bottom economy.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators on the streets of Tehran this past week. Protests spurred by a woman’s death in custody have expanded to include outrage over economic problems and frustration with moral strictures.

item.title: World Bank Leader, Accused of Climate Denial, Offers a New Response
item.description: David Malpass touched off a furor, including calls for his removal, when he refused to acknowledge that fossil fuels are warming the planet.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Brendan Smialowski/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: David Malpass was nominated to lead the World Bank in 2019 by former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Are Freed. Joy Ripples Across the Country.
item.description: After the largest prisoner exchange of the war, Ukrainians celebrated while anger coursed through the ranks of Russian mercenaries and military bloggers.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Azov battalion officers, including the commander, Denys Prokopenko, middle, spoke after being released in a prisoner exchange between Russia and Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: 2 Michael Jackson Impersonators Look Identical. The Resemblance Ends There.
item.description: Two imitators of the King of Pop in Buenos Aires offer a study in contrasts, reflective of Argentina’s deep economic divide. One man financed 13 surgeries, while the other draws on his sideburns.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Anita Pouchard Serra
item.media:description: Leo Blanco is a Michael Jackson impersonator in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

item.title: Waves of Russian Men Flee, Fearing Call-Up to Fight in Ukraine
item.description: Since the announcement of a new troop mobilization, civilians have realized they could not count on staying out of their country’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Passengers at Moscow’s Domodedovo airport in March.

item.title: Andy Byford, Ex-M.T.A. Leader, Steps Down as London Transport Commissioner
item.description: Mr. Byford, who was revered as “Train Daddy” during his tenure as the chief of the New York City subway, said he would move back to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Andy Byford, center left, the commissioner of Transport for London, and Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, tour a station on the newly opened Elizabeth line in May.

item.title: Bad to Worse for Russia
item.description: Vladimir Putin’s call-up of more troops highlights Russia’s continuing struggles in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian solders riding in Kupiansk, Ukraine.

item.title: Europe’s Shrinking Waterways Reveal Treasures, and Experts Are Worried
item.description: Drought combined with extreme heat this summer have painted a dramatic picture of Europe’s drying rivers and reservoirs.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Miguel Riopa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The underwater ruins of the village of Aceredo emerged due to the low water level of the Lindoso reservoir in northwestern Spain.

item.title: Viktor Medvedchuk, a Putin Ally, Is Released in Russia-Ukraine Prisoner Swap
item.description: The Ukrainian politician and oligarch had acted as the Kremlin’s primary agent of influence in Ukraine for years.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Sergei Supinsky/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Viktor Medvedchuk leaving a court hearing in Kyiv in 2021.

item.title: In India, Debunking Fake News and Running Into the Authorities
item.description: Alt News, an independent website, has emerged as a leading debunker of misinformation in the nation, but highlighting hate speech against minorities has put it on a collision course with the government.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alt News staff members in Ahmedabad, India. The site has debunked hundreds of cases of bogus information in India.

item.title: In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge Trials Come to an End
item.description: The last surviving leader of the regime that killed 1.7 million Cambodians lost his appeal on Thursday. Some victims think the long, expensive tribunal was a hollow exercise.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nhet Sok Heng/Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Khieu Samphan, 91, the last surviving Khmer Rouge leader, during his hearing at the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia in Phnom Penh on Thursday.

item.title: North Korea Denies U.S. Claims of Arms Sales to Russia
item.description: Pyongyang accused the United States of spreading “reckless” rumors, but added that it had the right to build and export arms.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexander Zemlianichenko
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, in Vladivostok, Russia, in 2019.

item.title: Lavrov Blasts Zelensky and Ukraine at UN Security Council Meeting
item.description: Insults, accusations and talk of war crimes and nuclear holocaust dominated the world’s premier diplomatic stage on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: The United Nations Security Council met in New York on Thursday to discuss allegations of human rights violations and war crimes in Ukraine.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A warning from Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Russian Presidential Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Calling up 300,000 reservists, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia tacitly acknowledged both Russia’s struggles and the existence of a unified Ukraine.

item.title: As Russia Retreats, a Question Lingers: Who Counts as a Collaborator?
item.description: In towns reclaimed from Russian occupation, Ukrainian officials are working to identify — and punish — those who helped the enemy. It’s dividing some communities.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
